text: being born in a conflict the country has
advantages and disadvantages I was
always surrounded by Jews it helped me
to be however I am so whatever I turn I
see something to cover I stand in the
middle I document everything happening
around me and I move it on the AP wire
to go all over the world I believe that
children are the real victim of any
conflicts so I always like to point my
camera towards children to show that
life for children is the same wherever
you are in the world they all seek fun
and joy and happiness in that particular
image it was in alomari refugee camp
near Ramallah these kids were playing
and chasing each other and this poor kid
was cornered into a wall really
terrified and that was the moment I
captured I don't know where this image
is from it's a looks like a little boy
might be a girl I'm not sure very dirty
face wonderful brown green eyes where's
that lie bahasa she's an Afghan refugee
living in a slum near Islamabad I spent
four years and a half in Pakistan I
decided to portray these children
because I've seen them growing in the
front of my eyes instead of being
remember there's Afghan refugees I
wanted them to be remembered by their
names and age back in September me and
many colleagues of mine made our
priority to document the refugee crisis
in Europe it wasn't about picture how
the picture looks like how the light it
was about documenting what these
refugees are passing through and there
is no better way to tell story than
being part of it it was overwhelming sad
at the end of your trip you built a very
strong relationship with the people that
you move with sometimes you get the
questions are you gonna forget us this
is the sad part where you always have to
say I'll never forget you
but life is going to takes us each one
into different directions
